Saudi Arabia drafts in up to 10,000 troops ahead of protests
 
 Saudi Arabia is drafting in up to 10,000 security forces to the north eastern Muslim Shia provinces ahead of mass protests planned next week.
 
 Desperate to avoid mass uprisings against the House of Saud, security forces have deployed in huge numbers across the region.
 
 King Abdullah is also reported to have told neighbouring Bahrain that if they do not put down their own ongoing Shia revolt, his own forces will.
 
 In response to the massive mobilisation, protesters are planning to place women on the front ranks to discourage Saudi forces from firing on them. 

 
 Saudis mobilise thousands of troops to quell growing revolt - Middle East, World - The Independent
 
 
Saudi Arabia was yesterday drafting up to 10,000 security personnel into its north-eastern Shia Muslim provinces, clogging the highways into Dammam and other cities with busloads of troops in fear of next week's "day of rage" by what is now called the "Hunayn Revolution".
 
 Saudi Arabia's worst nightmare - the arrival of the new Arab awakening of rebellion and insurrection in the kingdom - is now casting its long shadow over the House of Saud. Provoked by the Shia majority uprising in the neighbouring Sunni-dominated island of Bahrain, where protesters are calling for the overthrow of the ruling al-Khalifa family, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia is widely reported to have told the Bahraini authorities that if they do not crush their Shia revolt, his own forces will.

 
 A couple things shoot to mind here. First, I am having trouble seeing this as a shia uprising. Looking around the web and following facebook and twitter posts from the region, this looks an awful lot like another youth revolt to me. Not exactly shocking since unemployment for ages 15-24 is running 39.5% and unemployment for the 25-31 age groups is at 30% in Saudi Arabia. Life expectancy in Saudi Arabia pretty much sucks, so 70% of the population is under 30, while the ruling class is all in their 70s and 80s.
 
 As late as Wednesday King Abdullah was saying that things are "business as usual" in saudi arabia and that there were no protests that he was aware of planned in his country. Less than 24 hours later he had to issue the order to draft troops to be ready to put down street protests. 
 
 I think that washington and the house of saud have things dead wrong. Both have said that the Sauds dont really need to worry because they have hundreds of billions of dollars in reserves to buy civil peace. The king just announced a $35 billion cash giveaway to buy peace in the streets.
 
 A good friend of mine who is a Saudi summed it up for me pretty well in an Email. Now, this guy is not some liberal revolutionary fruitcake. He is a conservative, middle class guy in upper management at Saudi Aramco. He said "They are trying to bribe us with our own money. There are 20 million people in this country, but only about 100,000 in the ruling family, and that 100,000 takes 3/4 of the money for the oil produced here and we are sick of it"
 
 He makes a good point. The house of Saud is in power because of the British and the US...not because they actually have any real legitimate claim to power. As countries around them "fall" to democracy, I think it is going to be increasingly difficult for the Saudis to justify living under a monarchy...especially one as autocratic and brutal as the house of saud. 
 
 That is the other thing that I think the house of Saud, and even the US government which has kept them in power has underestimated in their plan to buy peace. People are willing to pay a STEEP price for freedom. $35 billion does not even begin to cover it. For hundreds of years men have gladly sacrifices themselves and their sons on the altar of freedom. The idea that a little cash thrown around is going to make that go away is foolish. Maybe not this year, maybe not next, but I think the house of Saud had better do their best to live life to its fullest, because their days are numbered.
